verses.text: Then Jesus spoke to His disciples: "There was a rich man who had a manager, and charges were brought against him that he was wasting his master's possessions."
verses.comment: Jesus speaks directly to the disciples, highlighting spiritual responsibility. The manager stands as a figure entrusted with what belongs to another, echoing steward imagery in other parables (see Luke 12:42).

verses.text: So the master called him and said, 'What is this that I hear about you? Give an account of your management, for you cannot be manager any longer.'
verses.comment: The demand for an account hints at final judgment, a recurring biblical theme. Compare to Matthew 25:19, where servants must answer for what was entrusted to them.

verses.text: The manager said to himself, 'What shall I do, now that my master is taking the management away from me? I am not strong enough to dig, and I am ashamed to beg.'
verses.comment: Shows internal reflection and crisis. The character's limitations and self-awareness evoke spiritual humility.

verses.text: 'I know what I will do, so that when I am removed from management, people will welcome me into their homes.'
verses.comment: Anticipates later teaching in this chapter about future security, preparing for what comes after this life.

verses.text: So he summoned each one of his master's debtors. He asked the first, 'How much do you owe my master?'
verses.comment: Connecting to forgiveness of debts, as in Matthew 18. The act of calling debtors hints at intercessory action—a spiritual principle.

verses.text: He replied, 'A hundred measures of olive oil.' The manager said to him, 'Take your bill, sit down quickly, and write fifty.'
verses.comment: The reduction of debt parallels themes of mercy and forgiveness, reinforcing Jesus’ teaching in other parables about grace.

verses.text: Then he said to another, 'And how much do you owe?' He answered, 'A hundred measures of wheat.' He said to him, 'Take your bill and write eighty.'
verses.comment: Again, generosity is shown. This act of easing burdens has spiritual implications, foreshadowing the later use of earthly resources for eternal benefit.

verses.text: The master commended the dishonest manager because he acted shrewdly. For the children of this world are more shrewd in dealing with their own kind than are the children of light.
verses.comment: Jesus recommends practical wisdom in light of spiritual realities. There's distinction between 'children of light' and 'of this world'—a theme found elsewhere (Eph. 5:8).

verses.text: And I tell you, make friends for yourselves by means of worldly wealth, so that when it is gone, they may welcome you into eternal dwellings.
verses.comment: Jesus teaches the use of temporal goods for lasting spiritual benefit. 'Eternal dwellings' implies a reward in the next life, linking earthly stewardship to heavenly treasure.

verses.text: Whoever is faithful in very little is also faithful in much, and whoever is dishonest in very little is also dishonest in much.
verses.comment: The principle of faithfulness applies to both small and great things, paralleling teachings on reward for fidelity in Matthew 25.

verses.text: If then you have not been faithful with unjust wealth, who will entrust you with true riches?
verses.comment: 'True riches' refers to spiritual blessings, which are far more valuable than earthly wealth. Reflects the idea of grace bestowed through stewardship.

verses.text: And if you have not been faithful with what belongs to another, who will give you what is your own?
verses.comment: A call to responsible stewardship, anticipating future reward. This connects to inheritance imagery found throughout the bible.

verses.text: No servant can serve two masters. Either he will hate the one and love the other, or be devoted to one and despise the other. You cannot serve both God and wealth."
verses.comment: This uncompromising statement highlights single-hearted devotion. Echoes the Sermon on the Mount, underlining total allegiance demanded for true discipleship.

verses.text: The Pharisees, who loved money, heard all these things and mocked Him.
verses.comment: Pharisees are portrayed as attached to wealth, spiritually blinded by materialism—an obstacle to understanding Jesus’ deeper message.

verses.text: He said to them, "You justify yourselves before others, but God knows your hearts. What is highly valued among men is detestable in God's sight."
verses.comment: Jesus exposes human pride by focusing on the condition of the heart. Divinely inspired Psalm 139 affirms that God knows our innermost thoughts.

verses.text: "The Law and the Prophets were in effect until John; since then, the good news of the kingdom of God is proclaimed, and everyone is pressing into it."
verses.comment: The transition from the Law and Prophets to the Kingdom proclamation emphasizes historical fulfillment in Christ—a shift from old covenant to new.

verses.text: "But it is easier for heaven and earth to pass away than for one stroke of a letter in the Law to fail."
verses.comment: The enduring authority of the Law is affirmed. Jesus stands as the fulfillment, not abolition, of the Law and Prophets.

verses.text: "Anyone who divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery, and whoever marries her who is divorced from her husband also commits adultery."
verses.comment: Jesus clearly teaches the sanctity and indissolubility of marriage, reflecting Genesis 2:24 and affirming lifelong marital union.

verses.text: "There was a rich man who was clothed in purple and fine linen, feasting luxuriously every day."
verses.comment: The rich man's extravagance symbolizes worldly security and neglect of true spiritual needs.

verses.text: "And at his gate was laid a poor man named Lazarus, covered with sores."
verses.comment: Lazarus is included by name, connoting dignity and blessedness despite earthly suffering—a recurring biblical theme.

verses.text: "He longed to be fed with what fell from the rich man's table; even dogs came and licked his sores."
verses.comment: Lazarus’s humility is contrasted with the rich man’s abundance, foreshadowing reversal in the afterlife.

verses.text: "The poor man died and was carried by angels to Abraham’s side. The rich man also died and was buried."
verses.comment: 'Abraham’s side' is understood as a place of comfort for the righteous dead, reflecting Jewish teachings about the afterlife and pointing to spiritual reward beyond death.

verses.text: "In Hades, being in torment, he looked up and saw Abraham far away, with Lazarus at his side."
verses.comment: Torment after death, contrasted with comfort for the righteous, highlights consequences of earthly choices. 'Hades' echoes separation as taught in other parables.

verses.text: "He called out, ‘Father Abraham, have mercy on me. Send Lazarus to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue, for I am suffering in this flame.’"
verses.comment: Even in torment, the rich man pleads for intercession. Mercy is invoked—an important spiritual concept, suggesting help from the righteous for those in need.

verses.text: "But Abraham said, ‘Son, remember that in your lifetime you received your good things, and Lazarus likewise bad things; but now he is comforted here, and you are in agony.’"
verses.comment: Abraham’s response affirms reversal of fortune and divine justice, echoing earlier themes in Jesus’ teaching (Luke 6:24: ‘Woe to you who are rich’).

verses.text: "And besides all this, between us and you a great gulf has been fixed, so that those who wish to cross from here to you cannot, nor can anyone pass from there to us.’"
verses.comment: Describes permanence of the final state after death. Spiritual consequences cannot be changed after life, echoing urgency of repentance.

verses.text: "Then he said, ‘I beg you, father, send him to my father’s house—’"
verses.comment: The rich man becomes an intercessor, reflecting concern for others and foreshadowing the importance of prayer and mediation.

verses.text: "‘—for I have five brothers—so that he might warn them, lest they also come to this place of torment.’"
verses.comment: Warning of judgment extends to concern for family. Teaching the urgency of repentance and conversion.

verses.text: "But Abraham said, ‘They have Moses and the Prophets; let them listen to them.’"
verses.comment: Affirms scriptural sufficiency for teaching and conversion. Moses and the Prophets are foundational witnesses to God’s truth.

verses.text: "He said, ‘No, father Abraham; but if someone goes to them from the dead, they will repent.’"
verses.comment: Implies that signs and miracles (even someone rising from the dead) may not effect conversion if people ignore divine revelation. Hints at Jesus' own resurrection and responses to it.

verses.text: "He said to him, ‘If they do not listen to Moses and the Prophets, neither will they be convinced if someone should rise from the dead.’"
verses.comment: Jesus concludes, emphasizing the sufficiency of scripture and foreshadowing His resurrection as the ultimate sign. Christ is both the fulfillment of prophecy and the one who rises from the dead. This final statement calls for faith that is rooted in revelation, not simply in signs.
